summary: 02/16/1999: At approximately 10:50 am local time, two car bombs exploded 200 meters away from a Government building in Tashkent, Uzbekistan. This attack was the first of six that took place within an hour of each other. At least 128 people were wounded and 13 killed in the combined attacks. There was some official speculation that these incidents were targeting Uzbek President Islam Karimov, whose motorcade was traveling through the city during the attacks. There were no claims of responsibility, but officials searched for 12 people believed to be involved in the bombing.
addnotes: This was one of six related attacks (cf. 199902160002-7). It was not clear which casualties resulted from which attack, so the total figures were divided equally across these cases to preserve the statistical accuracy of the database. Two motives were suggested for the bombings: the assassination of President Karimov; an intimidation tactic by religious extremists to show displeasure with current secular policies.
scite1: Alexander Koretsky, "Attempt To Blast Uzbekistan President Undertaken,” Russian Press Digest, February 17, 1999.
scite2: "Bomb attacks target Uzbek president, reports of 10 dead,” Agence France Presse, February 16, 1999.
scite3: Heather Clark, "Uzbek capital secure as police search for bombers,” Agence France Presse, February 17, 1999.

summary: 03/31/1999: Three Islamic militants hijacked a passenger bus, carrying 24 people, near Tashkent, Uzbekistan. The perpetrators, who killed three policemen, were eventually killed by police who stormed the bus. The hijackers demanded the release of Islamic extremists jailed for a previous bombing in Tashkent.
ransomnote: The perpetrators demanded the release of  Islamic extremists held in Uzbek prisons.
scite1: “Gunmen hijack bus in Uzbekistan, kill three police officers,” The Associated Press, March 31, 1999.
scite2: NA
scite3: NA

summary: 10/02/1999: Eight unidentified militants opened fire with submachine guns on the village of Qizil-Qiyoq in Sokh District, Fergana, eastern Uzbekistan. Uzbek Armed Forces returned fire and the clash lasted for many hours, but caused no casualties among local people or government forces. The villagers remained calm during the incident, most likely because a military detachment is stationed in the village, and the markets, shops and public service facilities all continued to operate.
scite1: "Kyrgyz Militants Attack Eastern Uzbek Villages,” Tashkent Uzbekistan Television First Channel, October 3, 1999.
scite2: NA
scite3: NA

summary: 03/29/2004: Four people were killed and around 20 injured by two female suicide bombers at the Chorsu Bazaar in Tashkent, Uzbekistan. Authorities blamed the Islamic militants for the incident.
target1: Indiscriminate civilians at a children's store and bus stop at the Chorsu Bazaar in Tashkent, Uzbekistan.
weapdetail: Female suicide bombers carried out the attack with unspecified explosives.
propcomment: Damage was reported to the Bazaar and surrounding stores.
scite1: Seth Mydans, “19 Killed in Uzbekistan; Terrorism Blamed,” New York Times, March 30, 2004.
scite2: “Clashes kill at least 23 in Uzbekistan,” The York Dispatch, March 30, 2004.
scite3: Burt Herman, “Explosions, 19 deaths blamed on,” Ventura County Star, March 30, 2004.

summary: 03/31/2004: Islamic militants clashed in a gun battle with police in Yalangach, a suburb of Tashkent, Uzbekistan. The incident left twenty perpetrators and three Uzbek police dead as well as five police wounded. The perpetrators reportedly blew themselves up with suicide belts, which ended the incident.
target1: Uzbek security forces in Tashkent, Uzbekistan.
weapdetail: Unspecified guns and suicide belts were used in this incident.
addnotes: The Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan was reported as the dominant threat in the country during this incident.
scite1: “Police, militants killed during Tashkent shootout,” The Globe and Mail, March 31, 2004.
scite2: Bert Herman, “Blasts precede gunfight: 23 killed. Islamist movement was reported to have been routed,” The Gazette, March 31, 2004.
scite3: Julius Strauss,” Fears of civil war rise in Uzbek capital as suicide bombers renew attacks: Islamist Terrorists Blamed; 42 People Die in Three Days of Violence,” Ottawa Citizen, March 31, 2004.

summary: 07/30/2004: Three people, including a suicide bomber, were killed and one person was injured as the perpetrator set-off an explosive device at the Israeli Embassy in Tashkent, Uzbekistan. The Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan (IMU), the Islamic Jihad Group (IJG), and Hizb al-Tahrir al-Islami (HT) each claimed responsibility. Officials suspected that the IJG was responsible for the attacks. The U.S. Embassy and the Uzbekistan Prosecutor General’s Office in Tashkent were also attacked in related incidents.
scite1: “Who is responsible for Tashkent blasts?” The Nation, July 31, 2004.
scite2: Muhammad Ismail, “Uzbekistan on alert as toll from suicide attacks rises,” Agence France Presse, July 31, 2004.
scite3: Burt Herman, “Suicide bombers target U.S., Israel Embassies; two Uzbeks killed,” The Associated Press, July 30, 2004.

summary: 07/30/2004: Two people, including a suicide bomber, were killed and one person was injured as a suicide bomber set-off an explosion at the U.S. Embassy in Tashkent, Uzbekistan. The Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan (IMU), the Islamic Jihad Group (IJG), and Hizb al-Tahrir al-Islami (HT) each claimed responsibility. Officials suspected that the IJG was responsible for the attacks. The Israeli Embassy and the Uzbekistan Prosecutor General’s Office in Tashkent were also attacked in related incidents.

scite3: Burt Herman, “Suicide bombers target U.S., Israel Embassies; two Uzbeks killed,” The Associated Press, July 30, 2004.

The Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan (IMU), the Islamic Jihad Group (IJG), and Hizb al-Tahrir al-Islami (HT) each claimed responsibility. summary: 05/13/2005: Georgiy Aleksandrov, a suspected suicide bomber was killed before he could attack the Israeli Embassy in Tashkent, Uzbekistan. Although he was carrying fake explosives, he was killed before he could undertake his attack. Aleksandrov had no affiliations with any known group.
target1: The Israeli Embassy complex in Uzbekistan
scite1: Aziz Nurioff, “Uzbek Official says Man Killed at Israeli Embassy Carried Only Fake Explosives,” The Associated Press, May 13, 2005.
scite2: “Suspected Suicide Attack Thwarted at Israeli Embassy in Tashkent,” Agence France Presse, May 13, 2005.
scite3: NA

summary: 05/13/2005: Thousands of armed protestors stormed a jail in an effort to free 23 members of the Akramia religious group in Andijan, Uzbekistan. At least nine people were killed and numerous others were injured in the incident. The government of Uzbekistan believed that the Akamia religious group was in contact with the outlawed, radical Islamic party Hizb-ut-Tahrir. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
motive: The protestors wanted to free 23 members of the Akramia religious group who were in prison in Andijon.
propcomment: A prison was damaged in this attack.
scite1: Bagila Bukharbayeva, “Nine Killed, 34 Wounded in Clashes in Eastern Uzbekistan,” The Associated Press, May 13, 2005.
scite2: “Uzbekistani Security Forces Storm School; Arrest, Kill Andijon ‘Guerillas’,” Agentstvo Voyennykh Novostey, May 13, 2005.
scite3: “AFP: Witnesses Claim as Many as 200 Killed in Uzbek City,” Agence France Presse, May 14, 2005.

location: The attack occurred at a police station in Khonobod.
summary: 05/26/2009: On Tuesday morning, in Khonobod, Andijon, Uzbekistan, assailants fired rocket-propelled grenades and small arms at a police station, killing one police officer, wounding three others, and causing minor damage to the police station.  Islamic Jihad Union (IJU) claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: The target of the attack was a police station.
motive: The specific motive for the attack is unknown.
weapdetail: Rocket-propelled grenades and small arms were used in the attack.
propcomment: The attack caused a minor amount of property damage to the police station.
scite1: BBC Monitoring Central Asia Unit, "Islamic Jihad Group Claims Responsibility For Uzbek Attacks- Fuller," LexisNexis Academic, BBC Monitoring Central Asia Unit, May 27, 2009.
scite2: NA
scite3: NA

location: The attack took place on Fitrat Street, Andijon, Andihon, Uzbekistan.
summary: 05/26/2009: On Tuesday afternoon at about 1400, in Andijon, Andijon, Uzbekistan, a suicide bomber detonated an improvised explosive device on Fitrat Street, killing one police officer and wounding three civilians. Islamic Jihad Union (IJU) claimed responsibility.
target1: An Uzbek police officer was targeted
motive: The specific motive for the attack is unknown.
weapdetail: An improvised explosive device was used in the attack.
propcomment: It is unknown if the attack caused any property damage.
scite1: Natioanl Counterrorism Center, "One Police Officer Killed, Three Civilians Wounded in Suicide IED Attack by IJU in Andijon, Andijon, Uzbekistan," Worldwide Incidents Tracking System, January 05, 2010.
scite2: BBC Monitoring Central Asia, "Man Blows Himself Up in Uzbek Eastern town Killing Policeman," LexisNexis Academic, BBC Monitoring Central Asia, May 26, 2009.
scite3: NA

summary: 09/28/2015: An assailant threw two incendiary devices at the United States Department of State embassy in Tashkent city, Tashkent region, Uzbekistan. There were no reported casualties in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
motive: The specific motive is unknown; however, sources suspected that the attack may have been related to a denial for a United States (US) visa.
weapdetail: Two incendiary devices were used in the attack.
scite1: "Uzbekistan: US Embassy Targeted by Firebombs," 24.kg, October 1, 2015.
scite2: "Incendiary devices thrown at U.S. embassy in Tashkent," Interfax, September 29, 2015.
scite3: "Incendiary device thrown at U.S. Embassy in Tashkent," Central Asian News Services, September 29, 2015.
